study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the presence and role of jasmonoyl-isoleucine (JA-Ile) in the lycophyte Selaginella moellendorffii and its involvement in stress responses.
results_summary: The study detected JA-Ile in S. moellendorffii and identified active enzymes (SmAOS2, SmAOC1, SmOPR5, SmJAR1) involved in its biosynthesis. Mechanical wounding stimulated JA-Ile accumulation, and JA treatment inhibited shoot growth, suggesting JA-Ile functions as a signaling molecule in stress adaptation.
population_specificity: Model lycophyte Selaginella moellendorffii (seedless vascular plant).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the preventive and reparative effects of isoleucine against copper-induced oxidative stress in fish enterocytes.
results_summary: Isoleucine pretreatment suppressed copper-induced oxidative damage (LDH activity, malondialdehyde, protein carbonyl) and prevented decreases in SOD and GPx activities. Posttreatment with isoleucine reversed copper-induced oxidative damage and restored SOD, GPx, and GST activities, though reduced glutathione content was not restored.
population_specificity: Fish enterocytes (in vitro)

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the effects of dietary isoleucine on tight junction proteins, inflammation, apoptosis, antioxidant defense, and related signaling molecule gene expression in the gills of young grass carp.
results_summary: Isoleucine deficiency or excess disrupted gill structural integrity by triggering apoptosis, impairing antioxidant defense, and altering gene expressions related to tight junction proteins, inflammation, and antioxidant enzymes. Appropriate isoleucine supplementation reversed these negative effects.
population_specificity: Young grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idella) weighing 256.8 ± 3.5 g.
effective_dosage: Six graded levels of isoleucine (3.8, 6.6, 9.3, 12.5, 15.2, and 18.5 g/kg diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoleucine deficiency caused skin lesions in a neonate using specialized formula for maple syrup urine disease and whether breast milk supplementation could resolve the deficiency.
results_summary: Supplementing with expressed breast milk led to biochemical and clinical improvement, including resolution of skin lesions, demonstrating that breast milk is a necessary adjunct to specialized formula to prevent isoleucine deficiency in neonates with maple syrup urine disease.
population_specificity: A neonate with maple syrup urine disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of increasing standardized ileal digestible (SID) Isoleucine-to-Lysine (Ile:Lys) ratios on the growth performance of nursery pigs.
results_summary: Increasing SID Ile:Lys ratios improved average daily gain (ADG) and average daily feed intake (ADFI) in nursery pigs, with optimal ratios ranging from 52.0% to 64.7% depending on the model used. Quadratic models predicted higher maxima than broken-line models, but both approaches indicated that the NRC (2012) requirement estimate of 51.1% Ile:Lys ratio was sufficient to achieve nearly maximum growth performance.
population_specificity: Nursery pigs (6- to 11-kg body weight).
effective_dosage: Dietary treatments consisted of 40, 44, 48, 52, 54, 58, or 63% SID Ile:Lys ratio.
study_duration: Experiment 1: 12 days (followed by a common diet for 16 days). Experiment 2: 18 days (followed by a common diet for 14 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the di-peptide isoleucine-tryptophan (IW) inhibits the expression and activity of matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP2) in rat aorta and its potential role in endothelium-dependent relaxation.
results_summary: IW inhibited MMP2 protein expression induced by angiotensin I (ANGI) in a dose-dependent manner in both endothelial and smooth muscle cells, as well as in isolated aorta. However, neither IW nor captopril inhibited MMP2 expression induced by angiotensin II (ANGII), unlike losartan.
population_specificity: Rat aortic endothelial cells (ECs), smooth muscle cells (SMCs), and isolated rat aorta.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which the whey peptide Isoleucine-Tryptophan (IW) inhibits the expression and activity of MMP2 in aortic tissue, comparing its effects to pharmaceutical ACE inhibitors.
results_summary: IW significantly inhibited ANGI-mediated MMP2 expression and activation in endothelial and smooth muscle cells, similar to captopril, and blocked specific signaling pathways (JNK in ECs, JAK2/STAT3 in SMCs). These effects were consistent in isolated rat aorta ex vivo.
population_specificity: Endothelial and smooth muscle cells (in vitro), isolated rat aorta (ex vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-isoleucine could prevent Mycobacterium tuberculosis transmission in a mouse model of long cohabitation.
results_summary: The study found that L-isoleucine significantly prevented bacterial transmission, reduced pulmonary lesions, and lowered bacterial loads in mice. The effect was comparable to other antimicrobial peptides tested.
population_specificity: Mice (infected and noninfected) in a long cohabitation transmission model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the maintenance requirements of isoleucine in poultry by measuring nitrogen balance and calculating the intake needed to maintain zero nitrogen retention.
results_summary: The study found that isoleucine required to maintain zero nitrogen retention was 20 mg/kg body weight per day, with a linear regression showing a positive relationship between nitrogen retention and isoleucine intake. The requirement was also expressed as 134 mg per unit of maintenance protein per day.
population_specificity: Roosters (poultry)
effective_dosage: 0 to 119 mg/kg body weight per day
study_duration: 5 days (48 h fasting, 72 h feeding and excreta collection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antihypertensive and cardioprotective effects of isoleucine-tryptophan and whey protein hydrolysate in spontaneously hypertensive rats.
results_summary: Isoleucine-tryptophan significantly reduced systolic blood pressure, improved coronary flow reserve, and lowered plasma and tissue ACE activity, comparable to captopril. It also reduced myocardial mass and matrix metalloproteinase-2 activity.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (n = 60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if lactotripeptides (LTPs) derived from casein, which include isoleucine, could influence blood pressure and related hemodynamic parameters in patients with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that LTP supplementation significantly improved systolic and diastolic blood pressure, pulse wave velocity, and endothelial function compared to placebo. These improvements were observed in both office and 24-hour ambulatory monitoring.
population_specificity: 40 nonsmoking volunteers with metabolic syndrome.
study_duration: 4 weeks per treatment period, with a 4-week washout between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoleucine is a limiting amino acid in low-protein diets for laying hens and its effects on laying performance and immune function.
results_summary: The study found that dietary isoleucine supplementation did not significantly affect laying performance, egg quality, immune function, or intestinal mucosal immunity in laying hens. Serum albumin, free isoleucine, and lysine levels increased at 0.74% digestible isoleucine, but other markers remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Lohmann Brown laying hens, 28 weeks old
effective_dosage: 0.54%, 0.64%, 0.74%, 0.84%, and 0.94% digestible isoleucine in the diet
study_duration: 12 weeks (from week 28 to week 40 of age)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the yield of 4-hydroxyisoleucine (4-HIL) from endogenous l-isoleucine (Ile) by co-expressing genes (ido, ppc, and lysC) in Corynebacterium glutamicum ssp. lactofermentum SN01.
results_summary: Co-expression of ido and ppc increased 4-HIL production by 29%, while adding lysC further increased carbon flux but reduced the conversion ratio of Ile to 4-HIL due to lower IDO activity. The highest 4-HIL yield was 95.72±1.52mM after 144h.
population_specificity: Bacterial strain (Corynebacterium glutamicum ssp. lactofermentum SN01)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the PNPLA3 rs738409 SNP on liver enzymes, metabolic indexes, and maternal and neonatal outcomes in gestational diabetes patients undergoing a lifestyle intervention.
results_summary: The PNPLA3 G allele was associated with higher liver enzymes and lower insulin resistance, as well as an increased risk of elevated liver enzymes during pregnancy but a reduced risk of large-for-gestational-age newborns. No interaction between genotype and lifestyle interventions (diet or exercise) was observed.
population_specificity: 200 patients with gestational diabetes enrolled in a lifestyle intervention trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of isoleucine conjugation in the jasmonic acid (JA) signaling pathway during grapevine fruit development and stress responses.
results_summary: The study found that JA conjugation to isoleucine is crucial for JA signaling, with grapevine GH3 enzymes (VvGH3-7 and VvGH3-9) showing activity for isoleucine. JA signaling primarily influenced fruit set and cell division but not ripening, and the enzymes exhibited differential regulation in response to stress.
population_specificity: Grapevine (Vitis vinifera L. cv Shiraz)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and tolerability of a topical cream containing L-isoleucine (Nutratopic pro-AMP) in treating facial atopic eczema in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study found that the pro-AMP cream, containing L-isoleucine, led to clinically relevant improvement in all signs of eczema and was well tolerated. The treatment showed efficacy as a steroid-free alternative for managing facial atopic eczema in children.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (6 months to 4 years old) with facial atopic eczema (2 female, 4 male).
effective_dosage: Applied twice daily to affected areas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of calcium in jasmonate signaling, specifically how blocking Ca(2+) elevation affects JA-Ile accumulation and plant defense responses against insect herbivory.
results_summary: The study found that neomycin selectively blocked OS-induced Ca(2+) elevation and JA-Ile accumulation in Arabidopsis, affecting downstream gene expression. The reduced JA-Ile level was partially due to increased CYP94B3 expression and subsequent JA-Ile turnover, not due to inhibited conjugation or substrate availability.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis thaliana (model plant)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and tolerability of a cream containing L-isoleucine (pro-AMP cream) for treating facial atopic eczema in children compared to an emollient cream.
results_summary: The pro-AMP cream significantly reduced facial eczema severity scores by 84% at week 6, outperforming the control group (50% reduction). Both treatments were well tolerated.
population_specificity: 107 children with mild-to-moderate chronic atopic eczema of the face.
effective_dosage: Applied twice daily (specific concentration not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clone and characterize the L-isoleucine-4-hydroxylase (IDO) gene from Bacillus thuringiensis and assess its ability to biotransform L-isoleucine into 4-Hydroxyisoleucine (4-HIL).
results_summary: The study successfully cloned and expressed the IDO gene, demonstrating its enzymatic activity in converting L-isoleucine to 4-HIL with high efficiency (89.28% conversion). The recombinant IDO exhibited optimal activity at 35°C and pH 7.0, with stable performance over 5 hours.
population_specificity: In vitro study using recombinant bacterial strains (Bacillus thuringiensis and BL-IDO).
effective_dosage: Not specified (enzyme kinetics measured with Km = 0.18 mmol/L and Vmax = 2.10 micromol/min/mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical application of N-methyl-4-isoleucine cyclosporin as a novel selective inhibitor of cyclophilin D activation in preventing renal calcium crystallization.
results_summary: In vitro, N-methyl-4-isoleucine cyclosporin prevented mitochondrial membrane depolarization induced by calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals. In vivo, it significantly prevented renal calcium crystallization, oxidative stress, mitochondrial collapse, and cell apoptosis in rats.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats and cultured renal tubular cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal standardized ileal digestible (SID) Isoleucine-to-Lysine (Ile:Lys) ratio for growth performance in pigs of different weight ranges.
results_summary: The study found that the optimal SID Ile:Lys ratio was approximately 51% for 10- to 22-kg pigs and 54% for 24- to 39-kg pigs, with improvements in average daily gain (ADG), feed intake (ADFI), and feed efficiency (G:F). Plasma urea nitrogen (PUN) levels were minimized at these ratios, indicating efficient amino acid utilization.
population_specificity: Yorkshire pigs (10- to 22-kg and 24- to 39-kg) and PIC 327 × C23 pigs (24.0 kg initial weight).
effective_dosage: Graded SID Ile:Lys ratios (e.g., 44%, 51%, 57%, 63%, 70% in Exp. 1; 39%, 46%, 53%, 61%, 68% in Exp. 3) with varying SID Lys and Leu levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining neural stem cells (NSC) with self-assembly IKVAV nanofiber gel (containing isoleucine) could enhance functional recovery in rats with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The combined transplantation of NSC and IKVAV nanofiber gel showed superior functional recovery compared to other treatments, with higher NF-200 expression and lower glial fibrillary acidic protein levels. Significant improvements in BBB scores and neurotrophic factor expression were observed.
population_specificity: SD rats with induced spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of reduced Isoleucine supply on milk protein synthesis and nitrogen utilization efficiency in dairy cows.
results_summary: Reducing Isoleucine supply did not significantly affect milk protein synthesis or nitrogen utilization efficiency but tended to decrease the milk protein-to-fat ratio by 3.8%, suggesting a potential need to reevaluate Isoleucine requirements.
population_specificity: Multiparous Holstein dairy cows at 22±6 weeks of lactation.
effective_dosage: 4.1% of PDIE (reduced from 5.2% in the control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of L-isoleucine on rat bladder carcinogenesis, comparing its impact with L-leucine under different dietary conditions.
results_summary: L-isoleucine supplementation significantly increased the incidence of papillomas and total tumors in rats fed the AIN-93G diet and increased the multiplicity of hyperplasia in the MF diet group, indicating a promoting effect on bladder carcinogenesis. No pathological effects were observed in the absence of a carcinogenic initiator.
population_specificity: Male rats (specific strain not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc and L-isoleucine regulate the expression of porcine β-defensins in intestinal epithelial cells.
results_summary: The study found that L-isoleucine increased the mRNA and protein expressions of porcine β-defensin 1, 2, and 3 in IPEC-J2 cells, with maximum effects observed at 25 or 50 μg/mL. The results suggest L-isoleucine can induce β-defensin expression in porcine intestinal epithelial cells.
population_specificity: Porcine intestinal epithelial cells (IPEC-J2 cell line)
effective_dosage: 0-500 μg/mL L-isoleucine (optimal effects at 25 or 50 μg/mL)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoleucine, among other branched-chain amino acids, could act as an amino group nitrogen donor for the synthesis of vesicular neurotransmitter glutamate in cultured mouse cerebellar neurons.
results_summary: The study found that isoleucine did not increase the labeling of cytoplasmic or vesicular glutamate after synaptic activity, nor did it maintain the amount of vesicular glutamate, indicating it was ineffective as a nitrogen donor compared to valine.
population_specificity: Cultured mouse cerebellar (primarily glutamatergic) neurons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of synthetic elicitor indanoyl-isoleucine (In-Ile) on the production of secondary metabolites, particularly anthocyanins and phenolic acids, in Vitis vinifera plant cell cultures.
results_summary: In-Ile enhanced anthocyanin production by 2.6-fold and significantly elevated phenolic acid accumulation, particularly 3-O-glucosyl-resveratrol and 4-(3,5-dihydroxy-phenyl)-phenol (6.4-fold increase). The elicitors did not suppress cell growth.
population_specificity: Vitis vinifera L. cv. Gamay Fréaux suspension cell cultures

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the standardized ileal digestible (SID) Isoleucine (Ile) requirement in low-protein, corn-soybean meal diets for 20- to 45-kg pigs.
results_summary: The study found that Isoleucine supplementation did not significantly affect daily weight gain, feed intake, or feed efficiency in pigs, with the SID Ile requirement deemed adequate at 0.43% (0.52 SID Ile:Lys). ADFI was slightly reduced at 0.45% SID Ile compared to 0.43%.
population_specificity: 20- to 45-kg pigs (barrows and gilts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding L-isoleucine to oral rehydration salts (ORS) would reduce stool output, duration of acute diarrhea, and induce antimicrobial peptides in children.
results_summary: L-isoleucine-supplemented ORS showed a trend toward reduced stool output and ORS intake, with significant reductions on specific days, but no significant difference in diarrhea duration or antimicrobial peptide levels between groups.
population_specificity: 50 male children aged 6-36 months with acute diarrhea and some dehydration.
effective_dosage: 2 g/L of L-isoleucine in ORS solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the interference of valproate with the isoleucine degradative pathway and explore the enzymology of valproate's β-oxidation pathway.
results_summary: The study found that valproate therapy moderately increased urinary excretion of the isoleucine metabolite 2-methyl-3-hydroxybutyric acid and identified MHBD as the enzyme responsible for dehydrogenating 3-hydroxyvalproyl-CoA. It also showed crotonase's role in valproate β-oxidation and isoleucine catabolism.
population_specificity: Patients on valproate therapy and fibroblasts from controls and a patient with MHBD deficiency.
interactions: Valproate (VPA) was noted to interfere with the isoleucine degradative pathway.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NIM811 (an isoleucine-containing cyclosporine analogue) attenuates CCl4-induced liver fibrosis in rats and explore its mechanism of action, particularly its interaction with cyclophilins B and D.
results_summary: NIM811 reduced liver fibrosis markers (hydroxyproline content, necrosis, and fibrosis scores) and suppressed profibrotic factors (TIMP-1, TGF-β mRNA, α-SMA). Cyclophilin B knockdown in hepatic stellate cells correlated with collagen inhibition, suggesting its role in fibrosis.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with CCl4-induced liver fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of l-isoleucine on obesity and glucose/fat homeostasis in mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: Isoleucine supplementation reduced body weight gain, epididymal white adipose tissue mass, hepatic and skeletal muscle triglyceride concentrations, and hyperinsulinemia while increasing adiponectin and upregulating PPARalpha and UCP expression in tissues.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat (45% energy) diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether l-isoleucine could induce beta-defensin expression and reduce bacillary loads and tissue damage in a mouse model of progressive pulmonary tuberculosis.
results_summary: Administration of l-isoleucine significantly increased beta-defensins 3 and 4, leading to decreased bacillary loads and tissue damage in mice infected with both antibiotic-sensitive and MDR strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis strain H37Rv or an MDR clinical isolate.
effective_dosage: 250 µg of intratracheal l-isoleucine every 48 hours.
study_duration: Treatment began 60 days post-infection and continued for an unspecified duration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Isoleucine (Ile) or Valine (Val) is the fourth limiting amino acid in broiler diets and their individual or combined effects on growth performance.
results_summary: The study found that Valine supplementation alone improved body weight gain to levels comparable to the positive control, while Isoleucine alone did not. However, both amino acids improved feed conversion, suggesting Ile may become co-limiting under certain conditions.
population_specificity: Ross x Ross 708 male broiler chicks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic role of isoleucine in mitigating hyperammonemia-induced effects in hepatic encephalopathy, focusing on its catabolism in muscle and brain tissues.
results_summary: The study found that isoleucine metabolism was higher in muscle than in brain tissue, supporting glutamate and glutamine synthesis, which may aid ammonia fixation. However, isoleucine's low turnover in the brain suggests it does not significantly contribute to TCA cycle function or energy formation in hyperammonemia.
population_specificity: Bile duct ligated rats (a model of chronic hepatic encephalopathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute modulation of glial glutamate uptake by the peptide histidine isoleucine (PHI) and its potential neuroprotective effects via the VIP/PACAP type 2 receptor (VPAC(2)).
results_summary: PHI significantly increased glutamate uptake velocity in cortical astrocytes by enhancing GLAST activity and cell surface expression, mediated through VPAC(2) receptors and protein kinase pathways.
population_specificity: Cultured cortical astrocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoleucine could improve blood glucose levels in glucose-intolerant or diabetic animals and elucidate its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Isoleucine significantly reduced blood glucose levels in normal, glucose-intolerant, and diabetic mice, with effects attributed to both insulinotropic and non-insulinotropic mechanisms. Chronic supplementation suggested an insulin-sensitizing effect alongside acute hypoglycemic activity.
population_specificity: Normal mice, glucose-intolerant mice fed a high-fat diet (HFD), and db/db mice (a model of severe type 2 diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if L-isoleucine was effective in treating hot flushes and if L-isoleucine, L-valine, or their combination reduced fasting serum homocysteine levels in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: L-isoleucine showed no significant effect on hot flushes compared to placebo, with a smaller decrease in symptoms than the placebo group. Neither L-isoleucine nor L-valine, alone or combined, affected fasting serum homocysteine levels.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women experiencing at least five moderate-severe hot flushes per day.
effective_dosage: Five capsules (500 mg each) taken twice daily (total 5,000 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether N-methyl-4-isoleucine cyclosporin (NIM811) could mitigate mitochondrial injury and improve graft function in rat liver transplantation.
results_summary: NIM811 significantly reduced liver injury markers (ALT, necrosis, apoptosis) and improved graft survival compared to controls, demonstrating efficacy in preserving mitochondrial function and cell viability.
population_specificity: Rats undergoing orthotopic liver transplantation.
study_duration: Treatment administered during cold storage and post-transplantation, assessed 6 hours after implantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of the DPP-4 inhibitor P32/98 (not Isoleucine) on impaired glucose tolerance in Zucker rats, focusing on hyperinsulinemia, hyperglycemia, and dyslipidemia.
results_summary: P32/98 improved glucose tolerance, reduced insulin requirements, and lowered triglycerides and non-esterified fatty acids in Zucker rats with impaired glucose tolerance, showing stronger effects in early-stage impairment.
population_specificity: Zucker rats (fa/fa) with incipient or manifest impaired glucose tolerance.
effective_dosage: 21.61 mg/kg body weight, administered orally once daily.
study_duration: 6 weeks for incipient impaired glucose tolerance, 3 weeks for manifest impaired glucose tolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Isoleucine (Ile) in plant defense mechanisms, particularly its involvement in jasmonic acid-isoleucine (JA-Ile) synthesis and herbivore resistance.
results_summary: The study found that Isoleucine is critical for JA-Ile synthesis, which activates plant defenses against herbivores. Silencing threonine deaminase (TD) reduced JA-Ile levels and increased herbivore susceptibility, but applying Ile or JA-Ile restored resistance.
population_specificity: Nicotiana attenuata (tobacco plants) and Manduca sexta (herbivorous insects).
effective_dosage: 0.6 µmol of JA-Ile (signal quantity) and 2 mmol of Thr (supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the anatomical substrate underlying NEI's role in increasing serum luteinizing hormone (LH) levels and its potential modulation of reproductive brain areas.
results_summary: The study found that NEI-immunoreactive neurons increased in the medial zona incerta in ovariectomized females without steroid treatment. NEI fibers were closely associated with reproductive areas and GnRH neurons, suggesting NEI may induce LH secretion through direct or indirect modulation of GnRH pathways.
population_specificity: Female rats (ovariectomized and intact, studied during diestrus and proestrus phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical manifestations, diagnostic methods, and treatment outcomes of three inborn errors in the isoleucine degradation pathway.
results_summary: The study found that deficiencies in beta-ketothiolase, SBCAD, and MHBD present with distinct clinical symptoms, requiring specific diagnostic approaches. Early diagnosis and treatment of beta-KT deficiency can prevent ketoacidosis episodes, while the effectiveness of interventions for SBCAD and MHBD deficiencies remains unclear.
population_specificity: Individuals with inborn errors of isoleucine degradation (beta-KT, SBCAD, or MHBD deficiencies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the in vitro effects of the tripeptide isoleucine-proline-proline (IPP) on osteoblast proliferation and gene expression.
results_summary: IPP increased osteoblast proliferation in UMR-106 cells and hMSCs, upregulated 270 genes, and downregulated 100 genes in hMSC-differentiated osteoblasts, including upregulation of PTHrP, BMP-5, and CREB-5 and downregulation of VDR and caspase-8. VPP and LKP had minimal effects.
population_specificity: UMR-106 osteosarcoma cells, human marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (hMSC), and osteoblasts differentiated from hMSC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoleucine could bypass ammonium-induced inhibition of the TCA cycle and support glutamate/glutamine synthesis in neurons and astrocytes under hyperammonemic conditions.
results_summary: The study found that isoleucine provided carbon skeletons for glutamate and glutamine synthesis, supporting TCA cycle function despite ammonium exposure, with notable differences in metabolic responses between neurons and astrocytes. Ammonium treatment did not inhibit the TCA cycle in either cell type, and isoleucine contributed to glutamine production in astrocytes.
population_specificity: Cultured cerebellar neurons (primarily glutamatergic) and astrocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoleucine could prevent liver metastases in a mouse colon cancer model and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Isoleucine prevented liver metastases in mice, independent of immune responses, by down-regulating angiogenesis via inhibition of vascular endothelial growth factor. It was found to be safe for human administration as it did not affect cell viability.
population_specificity: Mice with colon cancer liver metastases (including nude mice lacking T cells and natural killer T cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of isoleucine metabolism disruption in patients with MHBD deficiency, including the impact of an isoleucine-restricted diet.
results_summary: The study found that MHBD deficiency, a disorder of isoleucine metabolism, led to severe outcomes in male patients, including death despite treatment, while a female patient showed stability after one year of an isoleucine-restricted diet.
population_specificity: Two Spanish families with MHBD deficiency (two severely affected males and one less severely affected female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the role of a 6-substituted indanoyl isoleucine conjugate in regulating plant secondary metabolism, specifically volatile compound production in tobacco.
results_summary: Treatment with 1 mM of the compound induced three volatile compounds (farnesene, santalol, and tetradecanal) in tobacco leaves and regulated other volatiles compared to the control.
population_specificity: Tobacco plants (Nicotiana tabacum L. K326)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the carcinogenic potential of L-isoleucine in F344 rats.
results_summary: The study found no treatment-related adverse effects, including no changes in survival, health parameters, or histopathological lesions, concluding that L-isoleucine is not carcinogenic in F344 rats.
population_specificity: F344 rats (50 females and 50 males per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between branched-chain amino acids (including isoleucine) and nutritional status in hemodialysis patients over a one-year period.
results_summary: The study found significantly lower plasma concentrations of branched-chain amino acids (including isoleucine) in hemodialysis patients compared to healthy controls, with positive correlations between branched-chain amino acids and albumin levels, suggesting a potential link to nutritional status.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients (67 in study I, 70 in study II) compared to 20 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of spray-dried blood cells (SDBC) and crystalline isoleucine (Ile) on nursery pig performance, specifically focusing on growth metrics like ADG, ADFI, and G:F.
results_summary: The study found that higher levels of SDBC (5-9.5%) without Ile supplementation decreased pig performance (ADG, ADFI, G:F), but adding Ile restored performance to levels comparable to control diets, indicating Ile's critical role in meeting dietary requirements.
population_specificity: Nursery pigs (initial BW 5.9-9.3 kg).
effective_dosage: Crystalline Ile supplementation (exact amounts not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to refine the isoleucine (Ile) requirements for 7- to 11-kg pigs by evaluating its effects on growth performance metrics.
results_summary: The study found that digestible Ile requirements for optimal growth performance (ADG, ADFI, G:F) in starter pigs were higher than 1998 NRC recommendations but lower than current estimates when accounting for weight gain and feed intake. Quadratic responses indicated clear dose-dependent effects, with optimal digestible Ile levels ranging from 0.638% to 0.73%.
population_specificity: 7- to 11-kg pigs (starter pigs).
effective_dosage: Digestible Ile levels ranged from 0.37% to 0.83% in the diet, with incremental adjustments (0.06% in Exp. 1, 0.09% in Exp. 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synthetic isoleucine (as part of LITT supplementation) improved egg weight and hen performance in diets formulated based on lysine.
results_summary: Isoleucine (as part of LITT) improved egg weight and feed consumption within 2 weeks, but effects were lost after discontinuation. No significant effects were observed on egg production, egg specific gravity, or body weight.
population_specificity: Hy-Line W-36 hens (960 hens in eight replicates per treatment).
study_duration: Effects assessed within 1-2 weeks of supplementation or removal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether branched-chain amino acids, including Isoleucine, are second- or co-limiting for milk protein synthesis in cows fed a grass silage-cereal diet and to study mammary metabolism and amino acid supply.
results_summary: The study found that Isoleucine infusions did not affect milk production or composition, suggesting it was not limiting under the dietary conditions. Plasma Isoleucine concentrations increased only when Leucine was omitted from the infusion, indicating potential amino acid antagonism.
population_specificity: Five ruminally cannulated Ayrshire cows

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between CYP1A1 genotype and lung cancer risk and assess the effect of CYP1A1 genotype and antioxidant supplementation (alpha-tocopherol) on the smoking-lung cancer relationship.
results_summary: The study found no overall association between CYP1A1 genotype and lung cancer risk, nor did the genotype modify smoking's effect on lung cancer risk. However, alpha-tocopherol supplementation appeared to reduce lung cancer risk associated with smoking, particularly in those with the variant CYP1A1 allele.
population_specificity: Participants in a large cancer prevention trial cohort, including 282 lung cancer cases and 324 matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a nutritional supplement containing Isoleucine and other amino acids in reducing postprandial glucose excursions in non-diabetic overweight adults.
results_summary: The supplement significantly reduced venous blood glucose iAUC0-120min and Cmax compared to placebo, indicating improved postprandial glucose homeostasis. No significant differences were found in capillary blood glucose measurements.
population_specificity: Overweight, non-diabetic adults (60 participants, male and female).
effective_dosage: 2.6g of amino acids (including Isoleucine) and 250 mcg of chromium picolinate per serving.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report the successful management of a monochorionic twin pregnancy in a patient with Gitelman syndrome, focusing on the impact of heterozygous mutations in the SLC12A3 gene involving isoleucine.
results_summary: The study found that a heterozygous mutation converting isoleucine to threonine (I988T) in the SLC12A3 gene was present in both the mother and twins, with no adverse health effects observed over a three-year follow-up. Adequate supplementation of potassium and magnesium resulted in an uneventful pregnancy and healthy outcomes for the mother and twins.
population_specificity: A pregnant woman with Gitelman syndrome and her monochorionic twins.
effective_dosage: Oral or intravenous potassium chloride and magnesium citrate (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Throughout pregnancy until delivery at 36+4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biosynthesis, synthetic methods, and biological activities of jadomycins, including those derived from l-isoleucine.
results_summary: The study described the synthesis of jadomycin A and B from l-isoleucine and outlined the antibacterial and anticancer activities of jadomycins, but did not specifically report on the effects of isolated l-isoleucine.
population_specificity: Not applicable (review of synthetic and biosynthetic pathways, not a clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute BCAA supplementation, including isoleucine, improves recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage in resistance-trained athletes.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation (containing isoleucine) improved recovery rates for isometric strength, CMJ height, and perceived muscle soreness compared to placebo, with moderate to small but likely effects observed at 24-48 hours post-exercise.
population_specificity: Experienced resistance-trained athletes routinely performing hypertrophy training.
effective_dosage: 0.087 g/kg body mass (2:1:1 ratio of leucine, isoleucine, and valine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate an isoleucine-deficient diet and determine the isoleucine requirement for 80- to 120-kg barrows.
results_summary: The study found that isoleucine deficiency in a corn-blood cell diet could be corrected by supplementation, with optimal growth performance and lean mass achieved at ≥0.34% true ileal digestible isoleucine. Plasma urea nitrogen was unsuitable for assessing requirements due to feed intake variations.
population_specificity: Crossbred barrows (80-120 kg initial weight)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of medical foods high in leucine and low in valine and isoleucine on patients with methylmalonic acidemia (MMA), propionic acidemia, and cobalamin C (cblC) deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that imbalanced branched-chain amino acid (BCAA) dietary content, particularly high leucine-to-valine/isoleucine ratios, led to decreased plasma levels of valine and isoleucine and impaired brain uptake of essential amino acids, especially methionine in cblC deficiency.
population_specificity: Patients with methylmalonic acidemia (MMA), propionic acidemia, and cobalamin C (cblC) deficiency.
interactions: High circulating leucine levels decreased methionine transport across the blood-brain barrier in cblC deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of probiotic and prebiotic supplementation on tryptophan/BCAAs ratios, including isoleucine, in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found that probiotic supplementation significantly increased the tryptophan/isoleucine ratio compared to placebo, suggesting a potential role in modulating amino acid metabolism in MDD. No significant changes were observed in the kynurenine/tryptophan ratio or tryptophan/BCAAs ratio overall, but adjustments for isoleucine revealed a decrease in the kynurenine/tryptophan ratio in the probiotic group.
population_specificity: 110 patients with major depressive disorder (MDD), aged 36.5 ± 8.03 years, with a mean depression duration of 2.27 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified for isoleucine (probiotic: Lactobacillus helveticus and Bifidobacterium longum; prebiotic: galactooligosaccharide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the systolic blood pressure (SBP)-lowering effect of the lactotripeptides IPP/VPP (containing isoleucine) in Japanese subjects through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that IPP/VPP significantly reduced SBP in Japanese subjects, with a stronger effect in hypertensive individuals (-8.35 mm Hg) compared to non-hypertensive subjects (-3.42 mm Hg). The effect remained significant even at daily doses below 5 mg.
population_specificity: Japanese subjects with or without overt hypertension

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of imbalanced branched-chain amino acid intake, including isoleucine, on metabolic and growth parameters in patients with methylmalonic acidemias (MMAs).
results_summary: The study found that medical food consumption led to low plasma isoleucine concentrations, prompting paradoxical supplementation. Increased leucine intake was associated with adverse growth outcomes, suggesting isoleucine deficiency may negatively impact growth in MMA patients.
population_specificity: 61 patients with isolated MMA (46 mut, 9 cblA, and 6 cblB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the role of 17β-HSD10 in isoleucine metabolism and its implications in neurodegeneration, particularly in 17β-HSD10 deficiency and Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found that 17β-HSD10 is involved in isoleucine degradation, and its dysfunction due to mutations or abnormal expression impairs mitochondrial function, contributing to neurodegeneration. Restoration of steroid homeostasis or modulation of 17β-HSD10 activity may offer therapeutic potential for related diseases.
population_specificity: Individuals with 17β-HSD10 deficiency and Alzheimer's disease, as well as animal models of Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether acute tyrosine administration, which alters the plasma ratio of tyrosine and phenylalanine to competing amino acids (including isoleucine), enhances self-paced endurance exercise performance in the heat.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in exercise performance, power output, or physiological measures (e.g., core temperature, heart rate) between tyrosine and placebo trials, suggesting that altering the plasma ratio involving isoleucine did not affect fatigue processes or performance under these conditions.
population_specificity: Seven male endurance-trained volunteers unacclimated to exercise in the heat.
effective_dosage: Not specified for isoleucine (tyrosine dosage: 150 mg·kg⁻¹ body mass).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize traditional uses, pharmacology, and phytochemistry of Hovenia dulcis, focusing on its hepatoprotective, antioxidative, antimicrobial, and antidiabetic properties.
results_summary: Extracts from H. dulcis accelerate ethanol detoxification and exhibit hepatoprotective, antioxidative, antimicrobial, and antidiabetic effects, though molecular mechanisms are not fully understood.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BCAA supplementation, including isoleucine, could reduce delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) and muscle damage following squat exercises in untrained females.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation significantly reduced DOMS and suppressed muscle-force decrease compared to placebo. It also elevated plasma BCAA concentrations post-exercise and mitigated increases in serum myoglobin and neutrophil activation markers.
population_specificity: 12 young, healthy, untrained female participants.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg body weight (isoleucine:leucine:valine = 1:2.3:1.2), ingested once before exercise.
study_duration: Single-day intervention with measurements up to 3 days post-exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the morphological and chemical characteristics of glandular trichome types in Schizonepeta tenuifolia and understand the biosynthesis of its essential oil.
results_summary: The study found that peltate glandular trichomes produce terpenoids like (-)-pulegone, (+)-menthone, and (+)-limonene, with oil composition changing over the growing season. The yield of distilled oil was higher from spikes than leaves, though their compositions were similar.
population_specificity: Not specified (plant-based study)
study_duration: Observations made over 80 days after germination

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with Qiling Jiaogulan Powder (QLJP) could improve pulmonary fibrosis and pulmonary arteriole remodeling in broilers exposed to low temperatures.
results_summary: QLJP improved lung tissue structure, reduced collagen fiber formation, and alleviated pulmonary arteriole remodeling by downregulating genes related to the TGF-β1/Smad2 signaling pathway. It also reduced the expression of COL1A1 and MMP2, indicating potential benefits for pulmonary arterial hypertension.
population_specificity: Seven-day-old Ross 308 broilers (n = 240) exposed to low temperatures.
effective_dosage: 1 g/kg, 2 g/kg, and 4 g/kg QLJP in the diet.
study_duration: From 14 days of age until the end of the experiment (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antihypertensive effects of lactotripeptides (IPP + VPP), including isoleucine, in human subjects with high-normal blood pressure or untreated hypertension.
results_summary: Earlier trials in Finnish and Japanese subjects showed modest systolic blood pressure reductions (~5 mmHg), but recent trials in UK and Dutch subjects found little evidence of an antihypertensive effect or ACE inhibition in vivo. The study concludes that recent data do not support a role for lactotripeptides in blood pressure regulation, though population-specific effects may exist.
population_specificity: Subjects with high-normal blood pressure or untreated hypertension from Finland, Japan, the UK, and The Netherlands.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent research on the anti-cancer activities and mechanisms of Jiaogulan (GpM) and identify the compounds responsible for these effects.
results_summary: The study found that Jiaogulan contains over 230 compounds, primarily saponins (gypenosides), which exhibit anti-cancer effects in vitro and in vivo, including cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, and inhibition of metastasis. Clinical studies suggest potential curative effects, though mechanisms like immunomodulation and glycolysis inhibition were also noted.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro, in vivo, and clinical studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory activities of jojoba wax and its impact on the synthesis of extracellular components following topical application.
results_summary: Topically applied jojoba wax reduced LPS-induced secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8, TNFα) by ~30% and enhanced synthesis of collagen III and hyaluronic acid, with effects comparable to dexamethasone when combined with Triton X-100.
population_specificity: Human skin organ culture model (ex-vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective effects of jojoba seed cake extracts against acute paracetamol-induced liver toxicity in rats.
results_summary: Both simmondsin-rich (WE) and simmondsin-hydrolyzed (NE) extracts demonstrated strong hepatoprotective activity by improving antioxidant status and reducing inflammation-related protein expression (TNF-α, Bax, Bcl-2). The enzymatic treatment enhanced NE's hepatoprotective effects despite lower simmondsin content and in vitro antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: Rats with acute paracetamol-induced liver toxicity.
effective_dosage: 0.6 g/kg body weight, administered three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal nitrogen (N) application rate for mature jojoba plants under intensive field conditions, assessing its effects on nutrient status, growth, productivity, and soil nitrate accumulation.
results_summary: The study found that leaf N concentration reflected N application rates, with 1.3% N identified as the deficiency threshold. Higher N rates increased P levels in young leaves but led to nitrate accumulation in soil at the highest doses (370 and 500 kg N ha-1). The recommended dosage for intensive jojoba cultivation was 150 kg N ha-1, balancing productivity, cost, and environmental risk.
population_specificity: Mature jojoba plants grown under field conditions with intensive management.
effective_dosage: 50, 150, 250, 370, and 500 kg N ha-1 applied via subsurface drip irrigation throughout the growing season.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Jojoba oil's cosmetic applications as an 'active' ingredient, focusing on its benefits for skin conditions like dry skin, ageing skin, and atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Jojoba oil demonstrated benefits in strengthening stratum corneum integrity, recovery, and lipid ratio, with documented preclinical and clinical efficacy for various skin conditions, though some discrepancies in clinical data were noted.
population_specificity: Adult and juvenile populations with skin conditions (e.g., dry skin, ageing skin, atopic dermatitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dietary jojoba seed oil on broiler chickens' productive performance, meat quality, and carcass attributes under tropical weather conditions.
results_summary: Jojoba seed oil supplementation linearly improved feed intake, body weight gain, feed conversion ratio, dressing percentage, and reduced abdominal fat percentage. It also decreased cook and drip losses in breast and leg muscles without affecting internal organ weights.
population_specificity: One-day-old Ross-308 broiler chickens raised under tropical weather conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the multitarget action mechanism of Qiling Jiaogulan Powder (QLJP) in treating broiler ascites syndrome (AS) and verify its therapeutic effects.
results_summary: QLJP improved clinical and organ damage symptoms, reduced the ascites heart index, and may regulate lung oxidative stress, the cell cycle, and apoptosis by activating the FOXO3a signaling pathway to interfere with AS development in broilers.
population_specificity: Fast-growing commercial broiler chickens with induced ascites syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the growth, yield, and phytochemical behavior of three jojoba genotypes (EAI1, EAI2, EAI3) in response to different concentrations of Azolla extract.
results_summary: The EAI1 genotype treated with 30% Azolla extract showed the highest growth, flowering, fruiting, seed yield (3748-3839 kg ha-1), and oil yield (1910-2002 L ha-1). The 10% Azolla extract with EAI1 yielded the highest gadoleic fatty acid proportion (49.83%).
population_specificity: Jojoba plants (EAI1, EAI2, EAI3 genotypes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to prepare Jojoba oil dry nanoemulsion powders (JNDs) and evaluate their anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative effects in rat models of acute lung injury (ALI) induced by LPS or H2O2.
results_summary: JNDs demonstrated superior anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative effects compared to dexamethasone (DXM) in both LPS- and H2O2-induced ALI models, reducing inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, NF-κB p65) and oxidative stress (ROS, MDA) while increasing SOD activity and inhibiting caspase-3 expression. JNDs also improved lung tissue pathology by reducing bleeding and inflammatory cell infiltration.
population_specificity: Rat models of acute lung injury (ALI) induced by LPS or H2O2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the sponge-like protocol in protecting jojoba tissue cultures from fungal infections caused by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus niger.
results_summary: The study found that treatment with fungal ghost cells formation calculated critical concentration (FGCCC) of SDS, NaOH, NaHCO3, and H2O2 effectively prevented fungal growth in jojoba tissue cultures, with no fungal growth observed even after 10 days.
population_specificity: In vitro tissue cultures of jojoba (Simmondsia chinensis).
effective_dosage: FGCCC of SDS, NaOH, NaHCO3, and H2O2 (specific concentrations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Tunisian jojoba seeds on metabolic syndrome, oxidative stress, and related renal and hepatic complications in rats.
results_summary: Jojoba supplementation reduced body weight, fat mass, insulin resistance, oxidative stress, liver steatosis, and renal complications in rats fed a high-fat, high-fructose diet. The effects were more pronounced with a dietary approach compared to a nutraceutical approach.
population_specificity: Rats with induced metabolic syndrome via a high-fat, high-fructose diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of transdermal administration of jojoba oil on blood biochemical parameters in mice, focusing on serum non-esterified fatty acid (NEFA) levels and related gene expression.
results_summary: Topical jojoba oil significantly increased serum NEFA levels and upregulated Atgl in the liver, while showing a trend of reduced fatty acid trafficking-related gene expression in the skin. The results suggest jojoba oil may influence lipid metabolism via liver lipolysis and skin fatty acid transport.
population_specificity: Eight-week-old male hairless mice
effective_dosage: 4 μL of jojoba oil per gram of body weight, applied topically once

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether overexpression of the ScPIP1 gene from jojoba could improve drought and salt tolerance in Arabidopsis thaliana.
results_summary: ScPIP1 overexpression in Arabidopsis led to higher germination rates, longer roots, and improved survival under drought and salt stress, with reduced membrane damage and better osmotic adjustment. The study suggests ScPIP1 could be used in genetic engineering to enhance plant stress tolerance.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis thaliana (model plant)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether encapsulating tazarotene in a jojoba oil-based nanocarrier reduces irritation and improves therapeutic outcomes in psoriatic patients.
results_summary: The jojoba oil microemulsion increased skin deposition of tazarotene twofold, reduced PASI scores by 68%, and caused no irritation, unlike the marketed gel which showed irritation and lower efficacy (8.96% PASI reduction).
population_specificity: Psoriatic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing literature on the dermatological uses of jojoba, including its anti-inflammatory effects and applications in skin treatments.
results_summary: The review found that jojoba has anti-inflammatory properties and potential benefits for skin conditions like infections, aging, and wound healing, as well as roles in cosmetics and enhancing topical drug absorption.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal conditions for embryogenic calli formation from jojoba using zeatin and TDZ and to assess the antioxidant activity of the proliferated calli.
results_summary: The study found that MS medium with 0.5 mg L-1 BA and picloram was best for friable calli formation, while WPM with zeatin or TDZ produced the highest embryogenic calli percentages. Antioxidant activity varied by explant type and extraction method, with leaf-derived calli showing promise with hexane extraction and stem-derived calli excelling with petroleum ether extraction.
population_specificity: In vitro grown shootlets of jojoba (leaf and stem explants).
effective_dosage: 0.5 mg L-1 BA, 0.5-1 mg L-1 picloram, 1.5-2 mg L-1 zeatin, 1-4 mg L-1 TDZ.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability, in vitro drug release, and antimycotic efficacy of Jojoba oil-based emulgel formulations compared to commercial products.
results_summary: The study found that Jojoba-based emulgels exhibited excellent stability and varying drug release rates, with one formulation showing superior antimycotic activity against Candida albicans compared to commercial products.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and microbiological evaluation).
effective_dosage: Not specified (different concentrations of gelling agents used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of clay jojoba oil facial masks in reducing skin lesions and improving skin condition in participants with acne-prone skin and mild acne vulgaris.
results_summary: The study found a 54% mean reduction in total lesion count after 6 weeks of treatment, with significant reductions in inflammatory and non-inflammatory lesions. The DLQI-average score also improved, indicating better quality of life post-treatment.
population_specificity: 194 participants (192 female, 2 male) with acne-prone, lesioned skin and acne, mean age 32.3 ± 0.7 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound healing properties of jojoba liquid wax (JLW) on skin cells (keratinocytes and fibroblasts) and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: JLW showed minimal cytotoxicity and significantly accelerated wound closure in both keratinocytes and fibroblasts. Its mechanism involved Ca(2+)-dependent activation of the PI3K-Akt-mTOR pathway and MAPKs, while stimulating collagen I synthesis without affecting gelatinase secretion.
population_specificity: HaCaT keratinocytes and human dermal fibroblasts (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a methodology for monitoring oxidative degradation of jojoba oils under high-temperature conditions and to differentiate samples based on origin and processing methods.
results_summary: The study developed an FT-MIR methodology to monitor oxidative degradation, used PCA to differentiate samples by origin and processing, and identified chemical species changes during thermal treatment using MCR-ALS. Two spectroscopic indices were calculated to simplify oxidation reporting.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on jojoba oil samples)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the protein composition and in vitro digestibility of jojoba meal after oil extraction, including its protease-inhibitory activities.
results_summary: The study found that jojoba meal contains albumins (79%) and globulins (21%) with thrombin-, trypsin-, and chymotrypsin-inhibitory activities. In vitro digestibility of these proteins was comparable to casein and soybean protein concentrates and improved after heat treatment, likely due to protease inhibitor inactivation and protein denaturation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of polyamines in jojoba's adaptation to saline conditions during in vitro proliferation.
results_summary: Free putrescine and spermidine were higher in control treatments, while spermine was elevated in salt treatments. Soluble conjugated polyamines decreased with salt supplementation, whereas insoluble bound polyamines increased, suggesting their role in saline adaptation.
population_specificity: Jojoba (Simmondsia chinensis L.) single node explants cultured in vitro.
effective_dosage: 17.8 microM 6-benzyladenine and sodium chloride concentrations of 0, 56.41, 112.82, and 169.23 mM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate jojoba meal's ability to inhibit feed intake and limit body weight gain in broiler breeder pullets.
results_summary: Jojoba supplementation at 4% effectively reduced growth rate but increased feed intake compared to feed-restricted chickens. It altered hormone levels (increased growth hormone and thyroxine, decreased insulin-like growth factor-I and triiodothyronine) and impaired digestibility.
population_specificity: Broiler breeder pullets (chickens).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the absorption and distribution of jojoba wax in the body after ingestion.
results_summary: Most of the administered jojoba wax was excreted, but a small amount was absorbed and incorporated into body lipids, with the label diminishing over time. The study found trace amounts in internal organs and epididymal fat.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of chilling and high photon flux density (PFD) on photosynthesis and stomatal conductance in Jojoba leaves, and how these factors influence recovery and photosynthetic efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that chilling and high PFD caused significant photoinhibition in Jojoba leaves, reducing quantum yield and delaying recovery. Photosynthetic recovery was slower in high PFD conditions, and net assimilation rates increased significantly under elevated CO2 levels, suggesting potential ecological advantages for Jojoba in future climates.
population_specificity: Jojoba (Simmondsia chinensis) plants, specifically their leaves under controlled environmental conditions.
study_duration: Recovery periods measured up to 1 week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of jojoba oil (JO) on stomach emptying, intestinal transit time, and its digestion and absorption in rats.
results_summary: The study found that JO was mostly degraded and absorbed, with slower hydrolysis compared to triacylglycerols, and did not affect the absorption of conventional fats. No differences were observed in stomach emptying or intestinal transit time between JO-supplemented and control diets.
population_specificity: Rats fed purified diets.
effective_dosage: 9% (w/w) JO in the diet (half of the 18% total fat content).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different forest transformation modes affect soil microbial nutrient limitations and extracellular enzyme activity in abandoned jujube forests on the Loess Plateau.
results_summary: The study found that forest transition treatments significantly increased soil C, N, and P extracellular enzyme activities compared to abandoned jujube forests, with microbial metabolism limitations shifting based on soil depth. Vegetation type strongly influenced enzyme stoichiometry and microbial metabolic constraints.
population_specificity: Soil and microbial ecosystems in abandoned jujube forests on the Loess Plateau.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active ingredients and mechanism of action of the sour jujube kernel-five-flavour berry pair in treating insomnia.
results_summary: The study found that the combination primarily targets insomnia through eight hub genes, with jujuboside A showing strong docking to these genes and longikaurin A binding well to ALB and ESR1. The results suggest a potential mechanism for improving sleep.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study using databases and molecular docking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the susceptibility of Culex pipiens larvae to jujube oil and evaluate its potential as a botanical agent for larval control.
results_summary: Jujube oil demonstrated significant larvicidal effects, increasing larval mortality with higher concentrations and exposure time. Sublethal exposure prolonged larval development, reduced adult emergence, and altered physiological responses, including enzyme activities and hormone levels.
population_specificity: Third instar larvae of Culex pipiens mosquitoes.
effective_dosage: Distinct concentrations (specific amounts not provided in abstract).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether melatonin treatments could enhance the storage quality and antioxidant capacity of winter jujube during cold storage.
results_summary: Melatonin treatments (100, 150, and 200 µmol/L) maintained fruit firmness, delayed redness, reduced weight loss, preserved nutritional content (e.g., phenols, flavonoids, ascorbic acid), and enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity, with 200 µmol/L showing the best results.
population_specificity: Harvested winter jujube fruit at the white ripening stage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and optimize cobalt-based electrochemical sensors for detecting CD44, a biomarker associated with cancer, and compare their performance.
results_summary: The study found that HA-Co@Co3O4 electrodes outperformed HA-CoO@Co3O4 in detecting CD44, with a linear range of 1 × 10-5 to 1 × 103 ng mL-1 and a detection limit of 0.619 × 10-5 ng mL-1. The results aligned with conventional ELISA methods, demonstrating high sensitivity and selectivity for CD44 detection.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic efficacy and safety of oral Ziziphus jujube in mitigating uterine adhesion (UA) and improving pregnancy outcomes in a rat model.
results_summary: Z. jujube significantly reduced uterine fibrosis, improved endometrial regeneration, enhanced pregnancy rates, and inhibited extra-uterine adhesion formation without causing toxicity in vital organs.
population_specificity: Rat model of uterine adhesion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the role of ZjMAPKK4 in mediating cold stress response in jujube and its interaction with ZjNAC78 to regulate cold tolerance.
results_summary: The study found that ZjMAPKK4 was significantly upregulated under cold stress and positively regulated jujube's cold resistance. It also demonstrated that ZjMAPKK4 interacts with ZjNAC78 to regulate downstream genes (ZjICE-ZjCBF) involved in cold tolerance.
population_specificity: Jujube plants (Ziziphus jujuba Mill.) and Arabidopsis for heterologous transformation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Kadozan, a liquid chitosan formulation, in preserving the quality and extending the shelf life of Indian jujube fruit during storage.
results_summary: Kadozan-treated fruit showed improved preservation metrics, including lower respiration rate, weight loss, and decay index, along with higher firmness, nutritional content, and commercially acceptable rates. The 1:600 Kadozan concentration was most effective, increasing the commercially acceptable rate by 37.5% and reducing decay by 30.5% compared to control.
population_specificity: Indian jujube fruit stored at 15 ± 1 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal RF + HA drying process parameters for improving the quality of winter jujube slices, focusing on vitamin C retention, color, and drying rate.
results_summary: The study found that plate spacing, RF application time, and RF interval time significantly affected drying properties, with plate spacing having the greatest impact. Optimal conditions (100 mm spacing, 3 min RF application, 2 min interval) yielded high VC content (258.35 mg/100 g), improved color (a* -9.47), and efficient drying (0.64 g/min), while also reducing hardness and crispiness.
population_specificity: Winter jujube slices (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (process parameters: 100 mm plate spacing, 3 min RF application, 2 min interval).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different dietary supplementation levels of jujube fruit powder on the performance, biochemical parameters, and egg quality characteristics of laying quails.
results_summary: Jujube supplementation improved egg production and feed conversion ratio but had mixed effects on egg dimensions (width and length were lower in supplemented groups). No significant differences were observed in serum biochemical parameters or certain egg quality traits (shell weight, ratio, thickness).
population_specificity: 60 laying quails (45 days old)
effective_dosage: 5 g/kg (T1) and 10 g/kg (T2) of jujube fruit powder in diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects and mechanisms of Lactobacillus acidophilus-fermented jujube juice (LAFJ) on alleviating DSS-induced colitis in mice, focusing on gut microbiota, intestinal barrier function, oxidative stress, and inflammation.
results_summary: High-dose LAFJ (20 mL/kg/day) significantly reduced colitis symptoms, improved gut barrier integrity, reduced inflammation and oxidative stress, and restored beneficial gut microbiota and SCFA production.
population_specificity: Mice with DSS-induced colitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of Ziziphus jujuba syrup (ZS) with polyethylene glycol (PEG) for treating pediatric functional constipation.
results_summary: ZS showed significant improvement in therapeutic response, reduced encopresis and pain scores, and improved defecation frequency and medication adherence compared to PEG, with no reported adverse events or organ injury. Only PEG had minor self-limiting side effects.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-10 years with functional constipation referred to a gastroenterology clinic in Iran.
study_duration: 3 months (follow-up every 2 weeks in the first month, then monthly for 2 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of organic fertilizer (oil-cake amendments) on soil bacterial diversity, community structure, and enzyme activity in jujube orchards compared to chemical fertilizer (NPK).
results_summary: Organic fertilizer increased microbial diversity, altered bacterial community structure (e.g., higher abundance of Proteobacteria, Verrucomicrobia, and Bacteriodetes), and enhanced predicted gene functions related to biogeochemical cycling and plant growth promotion compared to chemical fertilizer.
population_specificity: Soil microbial communities in jujube orchards.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and classify C2H2-ZFPs in Chinese jujube and analyze their roles in stress responses and plant development.
results_summary: The study identified 77 ZjC2H2-ZFPs in jujube, classified into three groups, and found differential expression under water stress. Enzyme activity analysis showed increased SOD and H2O2 under stress, with ZjC2H2-ZFPs acting as key regulators in stress responses.
population_specificity: Chinese jujube (Ziziphus jujuba Mill.) plants under water stress and different fruit development stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the structural characteristics of a degraded jujube polysaccharide (DPZMP3) and assess its potential as a functional food component with enhanced antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study identified DPZMP3 as a homogalacturonan pectic polysaccharide with specific monosaccharide composition and molecular weight. The ultrasonic-aided Fenton treatment did not significantly alter its structure and may enhance its antioxidant activity in vitro.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of facility warming and Piriformospora indica culture filtrate (CF) treatment on fruit ripening and quality of winter jujube (Zizyphus jujuba Mill. cv. Dongzao).
results_summary: Facility high temperature (HT) promoted early fruit enlargement, accelerated ripening, and improved most quality parameters but reduced vitamin C content and antioxidant capacity. CF treatment enhanced HT's positive effects, increased anthocyanin accumulation, and mitigated vitamin C reduction.
population_specificity: Winter jujube (Zizyphus jujuba Mill. cv. Dongzao) trees cultivated under facility conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (CF treatment details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of jujube oxymel (JO) as part of integrated therapy for treating chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU).
results_summary: JO significantly reduced urticaria activity scores (UAS-7) and improved quality of life (CU-Q2oL) compared to placebo, with effects lasting longer than cetirizine alone. Minimal side effects were reported.
population_specificity: 92 patients aged 12-65 with chronic spontaneous urticaria.
effective_dosage: 30cc of JO syrup three times daily, combined with 10 mg cetirizine.
study_duration: 28 days of JO + cetirizine, followed by 4 weeks of cetirizine alone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the antiviral properties of jujube (Zizyphus jujuba Mill.) extracts, focusing on their potential to prevent or treat herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) infections.
results_summary: The study found that polyphenolic fractions from jujube peel and pulp, as well as the lipophilic fraction from the peel, showed strong inhibitory activity against HSV-1 by preventing viral attachment to host cells. The seed's polyphenolic component was distinct but not highlighted for antiviral effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how jujube polysaccharide (JP) modification via the Maillard reaction affects the antigenicity of soybean 7S globulin (7S).
results_summary: The study found that JP treated with 2.0% H2O2 had the highest degradation degree, which enhanced its Maillard reaction with 7S, forming a compact JP-7S conjugate that reduced 7S antigenicity. AF4-UV-MALS-dRI was effective in evaluating JP degradation and conjugate formation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of jujube fruit extracts on oxidative stress levels in rodent models.
results_summary: Jujube fruit extracts significantly reduced malonaldehyde (MDA) levels and increased superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) levels, but did not significantly improve catalase (CAT) levels. The study noted considerable heterogeneity in results, attributed to factors like animal model, extract type, and parameter sources.
population_specificity: Rodent models (specific species not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of bound phenolics extracts (BPEs) of jujube peel on relieving cadmium (Cd)-induced toxicity and its mechanism in Caenorhabditis elegans.
results_summary: BPEs significantly improved Cd-induced behavioral deficits, reduced lipid accumulation, and downregulated fatty acid synthesis-related gene expression in C. elegans and E. coli OP50. The treatment was effective at doses of 12.5 µg/mL, 50 µg/mL, and 100 µg/mL, with no significant differences between low and high doses.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans (nematodes) and Escherichia coli OP50 (bacteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of luteolin solutions on postharvest color changes and phenylpropanoid metabolism in winter jujube to inhibit reddening and browning.
results_summary: Luteolin treatment improved quality indexes, increased antioxidant capacity, and slowed down chlorophyll degradation and carotenoid synthesis, delaying pericarp reddening in winter jujube. It also inhibited phenylpropanoid metabolism and reduced anthocyanin and quercetin synthesis.
population_specificity: Winter jujube fruit (postharvest).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of red date polyphenols on glycemic control and oxidative stress in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but it suggests that jujube polyphenols may have potential benefits for glycemic control and oxidative stress due to their antioxidation, anti-inflammation, and blood glucose-lowering properties.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a synthetic microbial community to manage postharvest black spot disease in winter jujube by altering surface microbial composition.
results_summary: The synthetic microbial community reduced harmful fungi, increased beneficial bacteria, and significantly lowered black spot lesion incidence and size compared to controls and single-strain treatments. It produced inhibitory compounds, formed biofilms, and induced jujube disease resistance.
population_specificity: Winter jujube fruits (postharvest)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how L-Methionine (Met) treatment enhances winter jujube fruit's resistance to black rot by examining biochemical and molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Met treatment significantly reduced lesion diameter and decay incidence in winter jujube fruit, increased antioxidant enzyme activities (POD, PAL, CHI, GLU), and upregulated key metabolites and genes linked to disease resistance pathways.
population_specificity: Winter jujube fruit (post-harvest).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of ultra-high-pressure (UHP) treatment on microbial composition, odor, and taste quality of jujube juice as an alternative to traditional heat sterilization.
results_summary: UHP treatment at 330 MPa enhanced color, brightness, and stability of jujube juice, increased aromatic compounds, and influenced sourness without significantly altering taste. Microbial spoilage was categorized into bacterial clusters, with specific genera identified as primary spoilage agents.
population_specificity: Jujube juice (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Pressure levels ranging from 0-630 MPa (330 MPa had the most pronounced effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the molecular mechanism by which combining acidic electrolyzed water and high-voltage electrostatic field (AH) treatment preserves the quality attributes of postharvest Huping jujube fruit.
results_summary: AH treatment downregulated genes linked to respiratory metabolism, lignin and anthocyanin biosynthesis, ROS generation, and disease resistance, while upregulating ROS elimination genes, improving taste, color, and storage quality. The study suggests AH treatment inhibits pathogen infection and reduces ROS-induced damage.
population_specificity: Postharvest Huping jujube fruit

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how mixed enzymolysis combined with acetylation or carboxymethylation affects the structure and adsorption capacities of Jujube kernel fibre (JKF) for wastewater treatment.
results_summary: Modified JKF showed improved porosity, soluble fibre and polyphenol content, surface area, and adsorption capacities for nitrite, copper, and lead ions. Mixed enzymolysis with carboxymethylation enhanced hydration and heavy-metal adsorption, while mixed enzymolysis with acetylation improved oil-adsorption capacity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic value of multi-slice computed tomography (MSCT) in identifying esophageal jujube pit impaction and its complications.
results_summary: The study found that MSCT effectively identified jujube pit impaction locations, shapes, and associated complications, such as esophageal wall thickening and perforation, aiding in treatment planning. Endoscopic evaluation confirmed mucosal damage in most cases, with perforation observed in a minority.
population_specificity: 40 patients with esophageal jujube pit impaction, predominantly aged 58 or older (75%).
study_duration: Retrospective analysis of data from December 2018 to November 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of lysine crotonylation (Kcr) and lysine succinylation (Ksu) in jujube's response to phytoplasma infection and their impact on protein activity.
results_summary: The study identified 1656 crotonylated and 282 succinylated proteins in jujube under phytoplasma stress, with Kcr being more prevalent than Ksu. Key findings included the role of Kcr in regulating ZjPHGPX2 activity, an antioxidant enzyme, and its impact on enzyme function when modified.
population_specificity: Jujube plants infected with phytoplasma (Jujube witches' broom disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report cases of perianal infection in children caused by ingestion of jujube pits and highlight the importance of early diagnosis and treatment.
results_summary: Two pediatric patients presented with perianal swelling and pain due to jujube pit ingestion, which was confirmed via MRI and surgically removed. Both patients recovered well postoperatively with no recurrence or complications.
