population_specificity: Pediatric patients with perianal infections caused by jujube pit ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fermented jujube juice (FJJ) has anti-obesity properties by examining its effects on lipid accumulation and gut microbiota in obese mice.
results_summary: FJJ significantly reduced body and epididymal adipose weight gain, improved serum lipid parameters, and altered gut microbiota composition by increasing Akkermansia abundance and reducing the Firmicutes/Bacteroidota ratio and Helicobacter pylori levels in obese mice.
population_specificity: High-fat-diet-induced obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of jujube consumption on metabolic and mental health outcomes in individuals diagnosed with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Jujube consumption did not significantly improve fasting blood glucose, total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, blood pressure, depression, or anxiety scores. However, it led to significant improvements in waist circumference, triglycerides, HDL cholesterol, and stress scores compared to the placebo.
population_specificity: Subjects diagnosed with metabolic syndrome (MetS)
effective_dosage: 30 g dried jujube powder daily (15 g at 10 a.m. and 15 g at 4 p.m.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the fungicidal efficiency of dielectric barrier discharge cold atmosphere plasma (DBD-CAP) on Aspergillus niger spores and its impact on the quality of dried jujube.
results_summary: DBD-CAP treatment effectively reduced A. niger spores by 4.05 log (cfu/mL) in suspension and 2.67 log cfu/g on dried jujube, with no significant quality damage observed. The mechanism involved cell membrane damage, ROS elevation, and leakage of intracellular content.
population_specificity: Aspergillus niger spores and dried jujube samples.
effective_dosage: 70 kV for 15 minutes (spores suspension); treatment time not specified for dried jujube.
study_duration: 15 minutes for spores suspension; duration for dried jujube not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal water and nutrient supply scheme for jujube cultivation to improve yield and economic efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that combined irrigation and fertilization significantly improved jujube fruit quality (vitamin C, soluble sugar, sugar-acid ratio) and yield, with the N4P3W2 treatment showing the highest comprehensive score. The optimal economic benefit was achieved at specific N, P, and W application rates.
population_specificity: Jujube plants in southern Xinjiang, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal ratio of jujube in combination with wheat bran and citrus peel (WCJ) to improve efficacy and simplify manufacturing for preventing vascular dementia (VaD).
results_summary: The study found that WCJ (with jujube) improved cell survival by reducing apoptosis in vitro and mitigated white matter damage, astrocytic/microglial activation, and improved pupillary light reflex in a rat VaD model at dosages over 100 mg/kg/day.
population_specificity: Rat model of bilateral common carotid artery occlusion (BCCAO) causing chronic hypoperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cytotoxic, anti-metastatic, and apoptotic effects of Ziziphus jujube honey and commercial honey on MCF-7 breast cancer cells.
results_summary: Ziziphus jujube honey (JH) demonstrated higher phenolic content, antioxidant capacity, and diastatic activity than commercial honey (CH). JH more effectively inhibited MCF-7 cell growth, reduced migration, and promoted apoptosis via upregulation of Bax, p53, and p21 genes and downregulation of Bcl-2.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: IC50 of 170 ± 4.2 µg/ml for JH, 385.3 ± 4.5 µg/ml for CH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological efficacy and molecular mechanisms of jujube, focusing on its potential applications in medicine and food industries.
results_summary: The study found that jujube contains active components like polysaccharides, phenols, and triterpene acids, which exhibit neuroprotective and cardiovascular disease prevention properties. It also highlighted jujube's traditional use for calming effects and nourishing the blood, spleen, and stomach.
population_specificity: Not specified (general pharmacological and traditional medicine context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effect of Lactobacillus acidophilus-fermented jujube juice (FJJ) on chronic liver injury (CLI) in mice and explore its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: FJJ showed the best therapeutic effect among the interventions, reducing liver index, hepatocyte necrosis, and pro-inflammatory and fibrosis-associated factors. It also protected against mucosal barrier damage and improved gut microecology in CLI mice.
population_specificity: CCl4-induced chronic liver injury mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining jujube polysaccharides with near-freezing temperature storage could enhance the preservation of apricots by maintaining fruit quality and inhibiting decay.
results_summary: The study found that jujube polysaccharides combined with NFT storage preserved apricot color, reduced decay, lowered enzyme activity, and identified 1054 differentially expressed proteins linked to metabolic and stress responses, suggesting improved storage longevity.
population_specificity: 'Diaogan' apricots during storage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if aqueous extract of Christ's thorn jujube leaves (SLAE) could mitigate heat stress effects on production performance and physiological traits in dual-purpose laying hens.
results_summary: SLAE at 7.5 mL/kg diet improved body weight, egg production, quality, metabolic profiles, and antioxidant status in hens under heat stress. Higher SLAE doses showed the most favorable outcomes compared to control.
population_specificity: 25-week-old laying hens (Inshas strain) under subtropical farming conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ziziphus jujube fruit syrup, as an adjuvant to antihistamines, improves symptoms and sleep quality in patients with chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU).
results_summary: The study found that Ziziphus jujube syrup significantly reduced urticaria activity scores (UAS) compared to the control group, with notable improvement by day 28. Sleep quality also improved more significantly in the intervention group.
population_specificity: 64 patients with CSU who had hives for at least six weeks and did not respond to standard treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to reduce sucrose content in jujube juice and produce a functional beverage rich in rare sugars using multienzyme catalysis.
results_summary: The study found that enzyme treatment under specific conditions (pH 7.5, 60 °C, 7 h, DPE:L-RI ratio 1:10) reduced fructose content by 53% and yielded 29% D-allulose and 17% D-allose in 'Xiangfenmuzao' and 'Jinsixiaozao' jujube juices.
population_specificity: Jujube juice from 'Xiangfenmuzao' and 'Jinsixiaozao' varieties at the full-red stage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of acidic electrolyzed water (AEW), high-voltage electrostatic field (HVEF), and their combination on softening, cell wall degrading enzymes, cell membrane integrity, and antioxidant capacity in 'Huping' jujube during cold storage.
results_summary: The study found that AEW + HVEF treatment maintained higher firmness (15.7% more than control), better cell membrane integrity, lower CWDEs activity, and higher antioxidant capacity compared to AEW or HVEF alone. The combination treatment was most effective in delaying softening and preserving quality during storage.
population_specificity: 'Huping' jujube fruit stored at 0 ± 1 °C.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatments applied as interventions, not dosages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of radio frequency (RF) heat treatment on heat and mass transfer during the hot air drying of jujube slices.
results_summary: RF treatment reduced drying time, enhanced internal temperature, promoted consistent heat and mass transfer, and accelerated moisture diffusion in jujube slices. The later the RF treatment was applied, the greater the increase in internal temperature and the faster the decrease in moisture content.
population_specificity: Jujube slices (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (experimental conditions varied by drying stage).
study_duration: Not specified (duration tied to drying process).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of varying dietary levels of jujube powder on broiler growth performance, nutrient digestibility, immune function, antioxidant status, and gut microbiota.
results_summary: Adding 8% jujube powder significantly improved broiler weight gain and organic matter digestibility, while 10% enhanced metabolic energy. Jujube powder (4-10%) also boosted immune markers (IgA, IgG, IgM, sCD4), antioxidant capacity (T-AOC, SOD), and beneficial gut microbiota (Firmicutes, Lactobacillus), while reducing harmful bacteria (Proteobacteria, Enterobacter) and oxidative stress (MDA).
population_specificity: Cobb broilers (576 birds, randomized into 6 treatment groups).
study_duration: 42 days (divided into starter [0-21 days] and finisher [22-42 days] phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the sleep-enhancing activity and mechanism of action of a fermented aqueous extract of jujube seeds (ZW-FM) in rodent models.
results_summary: ZW-FM increased sleep time, particularly δ-wave time during NREM sleep, reduced sleep latency, and counteracted caffeine-induced insomnia by modulating GABAergic mechanisms. The effects were dose-dependent and inhibited by GABAA receptor antagonists.
population_specificity: ICR mice and Sprague Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ziziphus Jujuba Mill (Z.J) could reduce LPS-induced inflammatory responses in an experimental model of acute lung injury (ALI).
results_summary: Z.J extracts (100 and 200 mg/kg) effectively reduced inflammatory cell influx, lung wet-to-dry ratio, histopathological damage, and TNF-α levels in LPS-induced ALI mice, comparable to dexamethasone.
population_specificity: Male BALB/c mice with LPS-induced acute lung injury.
effective_dosage: 100 and 200 mg/kg, administered intraperitoneally at 1, 11, and 23 hours post-LPS injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of acidic electrolyzed water (AEW), a high-voltage electrostatic field (HVEF), and their combination (AEW + HVEF) on preserving the storage quality of Huping jujube.
results_summary: The combined AEW + HVEF treatment maintained higher nutrient levels, better taste compounds, lower deterioration metrics, and delayed color changes compared to individual treatments, enhancing preservation quality. It also improved antioxidant activity and appearance retention.
population_specificity: Huping jujube fruits stored at 0 ± 1 °C.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment methods described but not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a synbiotic containing jujube powder could enhance the therapeutic effects of a cancer vaccine in mice with MC38 cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that jujube powder, combined with Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG, reshaped gut microbiota, improved lipid metabolism, and increased CD8+ T cell infiltration, enhancing the cancer vaccine's efficacy. Jujube specifically enriched microbial diversity and supported beneficial bacteria in Lachnospiraceae.
population_specificity: MC38 cancer cell-bearing mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether jujube vinegar's hypolipidemic and antioxidant effects are mediated through gut microbiome regulation in hyperlipidemic mice.
results_summary: Jujube vinegar significantly reduced body weight, blood lipids, and oxidative stress markers while improving gut microbiome diversity and beneficial bacterial populations in high-fat diet mice. It also modulated key metabolic pathways linked to lipid metabolism and antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Male ICR mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular mechanisms underlying the recovery of jujube trees from Jujube witches' broom disease (JWB) after treatment with oxytetracycline hydrochloride (OTC-HCl).
results_summary: OTC-HCl trunk injection recovered over 86% of mildly JWB-diseased jujube trees. Transcriptomic analysis revealed 755 differentially expressed genes (DEGs), with most DEGs in diseased trees showing reversed expression patterns after treatment, indicating restoration of gene function.
population_specificity: Jujube trees infected with JWB phytoplasma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifungal effects of surfactin on Botrytis cinerea and its potential to preserve the quality of winter jujube by maintaining fatty acid composition.
results_summary: Surfactin significantly inhibited B. cinerea growth, reduced gray mold incidence in winter jujube, and preserved fatty acid composition. It also mitigated adverse effects from mechanical injury on the fruit.
population_specificity: Winter jujube fruit inoculated with Botrytis cinerea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of four disease-controlling agents (chlorothalonil, CuCl2, harpin, and melatonin) in improving postharvest quality of jujube fruit by reducing disease severity, enhancing antioxidant accumulation, and delaying senescence.
results_summary: All four agents improved postharvest jujube fruit quality by reducing disease severity, increasing antioxidant content and capacity, and delaying senescence, with CuCl2 being the most effective overall. Chlorothalonil showed the highest disease inhibition but left residues, while melatonin had the highest antioxidant enhancement.
population_specificity: Postharvest jujube fruit under low-temperature conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether jujube powder could enhance immune response to vaccination by modulating gut microbiota in mice.
results_summary: Jujube powder (800 mg/kg daily) significantly increased HSA-specific IgG1 concentration in serum and boosted immune markers (macrophages, B cells, plasma cells) without increasing myeloid cells, suggesting a distinct mechanism from fecal microbiota transplantation. It also altered gut microbiota composition, favoring amino acid metabolism pathways linked to immune enhancement.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dietary dried jujube fruit powder (DJFP) supplementation affects growth performance, antioxidant stability, meat composition, and nutritional quality in broilers.
results_summary: DJFP supplementation improved broiler growth performance, antioxidant stability, and meat quality, including increased protein content, reduced fat content, and enhanced amino acid and fatty acid profiles, with the most marked effects at 100 g/kg DJFP.
population_specificity: Cobb broilers (1-day-old, unsexed, 360 total).
effective_dosage: 50 g/kg (P1), 100 g/kg (P2), and 150 g/kg (P3) DJFP in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of acidic electrolyzed water (AEW) combined with modified atmosphere packaging (MAP) in preserving the quality and delaying postharvest senescence of jujube during cold storage.
results_summary: The combined AEW + MAP treatment significantly maintained higher storage quality by suppressing softening, weight loss, and color degradation while enhancing antioxidant capacity and reducing oxidative damage compared to individual treatments. It also slowed the rate of quality deterioration and achieved a higher comprehensive score in principal component analysis.
population_specificity: Jujube fruit stored at 1 ± 0.5°C.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment involved AEW + MAP application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the hepatoprotective effect of dried red jujube fruit extract on aminotransferase levels in acetaminophen-induced acute hepatotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that dried red jujube fruit extract significantly reduced ALT and AST levels in a dose-dependent manner, with the highest dose (280 mg/kg BW) being the most effective. A strong negative correlation was observed between the extract doses and aminotransferase levels.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 70 mg/kg BW, 140 mg/kg BW, and 280 mg/kg BW, administered for 10 consecutive days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Meyerozyma caribbica yeast in controlling Alternaria alternata-induced black spot rot in postharvest jujube fruits and explore its biofilm formation mechanism.
results_summary: M. caribbica treatment significantly reduced A. alternata decay in jujube fruits by colonizing wounds, adhering to hyphae, and secreting extracellular substances like phenylethanol. Phenylalanine enhanced phenylethanol secretion and improved the yeast's biocontrol performance against black spot rot.
population_specificity: Postharvest jujube fruits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of UV-C treatment on delaying senescence and improving the quality of 'Lingwu long' jujubes during storage.
results_summary: UV-C treatment reduced respiration rate and decay index, delayed firmness reduction by lowering cell wall degrading enzyme activities, enhanced antioxidant capacity, and increased phenolic compounds in jujube fruit.
population_specificity: 'Lingwu long' jujubes stored at 4 ± 1 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how heat shock (HT), 1-methylcyclopropene (1-MCP), or their combination affects the cuticle wax of jujube fruit during cold storage to improve shelf life.
results_summary: HT, 1-MCP, or HT + 1-MCP treatments resulted in a smoother wax layer, fewer micro-cracks, and increased wax content at 45 days of cold storage. Transcriptomics showed upregulation of genes (FATB, FAB2, FAD2, CYP716A) linked to wax maintenance.
population_specificity: Jujube fruit (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatments applied but exact concentrations/frequencies not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize ultrasonic-assisted extraction conditions for sour jujube to maximize the yield of total saponins, flavonoids, and phenolics, and evaluate its antioxidant effects in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: The study found that optimized methanol and ethanol extraction improved the efficiency of target compounds, with ethanol yielding higher TFC and TPC, while methanol yielded higher TSC. In vivo experiments showed jujube extract protected against oxidative stress and extended the lifespan of Drosophila.
population_specificity: Drosophila (fruit flies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize fluorescent carbon dots (CDs) from wild jujube and dl-tryptophan for use as a sensitive "off-on" fluorescent probe to detect oxalic acid.
results_summary: The CDs exhibited strong blue fluorescence under UV light, with Hg2+ quenching the fluorescence and oxalic acid restoring it. The probe successfully detected oxalic acid in tomato and cherry tomato samples with high sensitivity and a low detection limit.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of melatonin treatment on the visual appearance and physicochemical properties of postharvest jujube fruits stored at 0°C for 15 days.
results_summary: Melatonin treatment improved the crispness of jujube fruits, delayed weight loss and firmness decline, and stabilized total soluble solids and titratable acidity. It also enhanced antioxidant capacity by increasing ascorbic acid content and superoxide dismutase activity while reducing malonaldehyde content, with 50 µM melatonin showing the best results.
population_specificity: Postharvest jujube fruits (Ziziphus jujuba Mill. cv. Shucuizao)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glycine betaine (GB) treatment could maintain postharvest quality and delay softening in winter jujube fruit by enhancing antioxidant metabolism and energy levels.
results_summary: GB treatment effectively preserved cell wall components, boosted antioxidant enzyme activities, reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS), and increased energy metabolism, thereby delaying fruit softening.
population_specificity: Fresh winter jujubes (Zizyphus jujuba Mill. cv. Dongzao)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of four different sterilization treatments on jujube juice as substrates for producing a probiotic beverage fermented by Lactobacillus plantarum.
results_summary: The study found that pulsed strong light sterilization (PLS) and cold plasma sterilization (CPS) improved the stability of jujube juice, with PLS-treated juice showing no significant difference in sensory and nutritional quality compared to the control and better color than other treatments. The growth of L. plantarum was unaffected by sterilization methods, but autoclaving and pasteurization increased particle size and reduced reducing sugar content.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on jujube juice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different radio frequency (RF) application stages during hot air drying on the quality attributes (microstructure, moisture absorption rate, color, and ascorbic acid retention) of jujube slices.
results_summary: The study found that hot air drying combined with RF at different stages improved the quality of jujube slices, with the early-stage RF application (E-HA + RF) showing the best results in cell roundness reduction, while the middle-stage RF application (M-HA + RF) achieved the best color retention and ascorbic acid preservation.
population_specificity: Jujube slices (agricultural product, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (drying methods: E-HA + RF, M-HA + RF, L-HA + RF, W-HA + RF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different mulching measures (clean tillage, jujube branches mulching, and white clover planting) on soil moisture, soil temperature, and jujube growth in rain-fed orchards.
results_summary: Jujube branches mulching (JBM) increased soil moisture, reduced soil water deficit, regulated soil temperature, and significantly improved jujube growth (leaf area index and stem diameter) compared to clean tillage and white clover planting. White clover planting led to the greatest soil water deficit due to competition with jujube for water.
population_specificity: Rain-fed jujube orchards

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the extraction of swertisin from sour Jujube seed and evaluate its antioxidant effects in vitro and in C. elegans, as well as explore its potential mechanisms using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: Swertisin demonstrated significant free radical scavenging ability and enhanced antioxidative enzyme activity (GST-4, SOD-3, GSH-PX) while reducing reactive oxygen species and malondialdehyde accumulation in C. elegans, protecting them from oxidative stress. Network pharmacology identified 139 antioxidant targets and 70 enriched pathways, suggesting potential multi-target therapeutic applications.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of selenium yeast and jujube powder on the structural and functional properties of post-mortem myofibrillar protein in white feather broilers.
results_summary: The study found that increasing concentrations of selenium yeast and jujube powder improved the structural integrity and functional properties of myofibrillar protein, including increased α-helix content, solubility, emulsification, and foaming, while reducing β-folding content and turbidity. The best results were observed with a combination of high-dose selenium yeast and jujube powder.
population_specificity: White feather broilers
effective_dosage: Jujube powder: 8% to replace corn; selenium yeast: 0, 0.3, and 0.6 mg/kg
interactions: Significant interactions noted between selenium yeast and jujube powder in improving protein properties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 1-methylcyclopropene (1-MCP) and salicylic acid (SA) treatments on preserving the quality and extending the shelf life of winter jujube fruit.
results_summary: Both 1-MCP and SA treatments improved fruit quality by reducing weight loss, respiratory rate, and oxidative damage while enhancing firmness, antioxidant enzyme activities, and nutritional content. The combined 1-MCP+SA treatment showed the most significant preservation effects.
population_specificity: Winter jujube fruit (postharvest).
study_duration: Shelf life duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exogenous salicylic acid (SA) treatment on antioxidant and hormone levels in winter jujube during shelf life at 4°C.
results_summary: SA treatment maintained fruit quality (firmness, color, acidity) and reduced oxidative stress by enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity and increasing antioxidant substances. It also modulated hormone levels, increasing abscisic acid and SA while decreasing jasmonic acid.
population_specificity: Winter jujube fruit

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of D. nepalensis on the epiphytic microbiome and postharvest decay of jujube.
results_summary: D. nepalensis reduced fungal decay, maintained fruit firmness, and delayed discoloration in jujube. It altered fungal communities, decreasing pathogenic fungi like Alternaria and Penicillium while increasing beneficial bacteria like Pantoea.
population_specificity: Postharvest jujube fruit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify drought-responsive microRNAs and their target genes in Chinese jujube to understand its molecular mechanisms of drought resistance.
results_summary: The study identified 43 known and 431 novel miRNAs in Chinese jujube, with 28 and 61 miRNAs differentially expressed under drought stress in two jujube varieties. Nine drought-related miRNAs and seven target genes were confirmed, showing negative correlation in expression levels.
population_specificity: Two genotypes of Chinese jujube ("Dongzao" and "Zanhuangdazao") under drought stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different organic fertilizers on the physiological growth, photosynthetic characteristics, reproductive growth, and nutritional quality of Pear-jujube in the Loess Plateau.
results_summary: Organic fertilizers significantly improved Pear-jujube's physiological growth, photosynthetic efficiency, reproductive growth, and nutritional quality, with soybean cake fertilizer (SC) showing the most significant effects, including increased yield, chlorophyll content, and fruit quality metrics like total soluble solids and vitamin C.
population_specificity: Pear-jujube trees in the hilly and gully area of the Loess Plateau in northern Shaanxi.
effective_dosage: Not specified (different organic fertilizers applied, but exact amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (field study duration not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cold atmospheric plasma (CAP) treatment on delaying ripening, preserving quality, and extending the shelf life of winter jujube during storage.
results_summary: CAP treatment delayed ripening and reduced microbial contamination but did not affect weight loss or moisture content. A 20-minute CAP treatment maintained phenolic content, antioxidant activity, and reduced oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Winter jujube (Ziziphus jujuba Mill. cv. Dongzao) fruits.
effective_dosage: CAP exposure times of 0, 5, 10, and 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the phytonutrients, biological functions, metabolism of bioactive compounds, and applications of wild jujube to provide a scientific reference for its development and utilization.
results_summary: The study found that wild jujube has antioxidant, antibacterial, and anti-inflammatory properties, and its seeds may benefit central nervous system diseases, improving sleep quality and enhancing learning and memory.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of ozone treatment in reducing postharvest decay of winter jujube by altering microbial community structure on the fruit surface.
results_summary: Ozone treatment (2.5, 5, and 10 μL L-1) significantly reduced postharvest decay of winter jujube by days 10 and 15, altered bacterial and fungal communities, and inhibited metabolic pathways linked to decay.
population_specificity: Winter jujube (Ziziphus jujuba Miller cv. Dongzao) from Huanghua City, Hebei, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the extraction of cAMP from jujube using ultra-high pressure extraction (UHPE) and evaluate its potential anti-allergic effects in a peanut allergy mouse model.
results_summary: The study found that optimal cAMP yield (1223.2 μg/g) was achieved at 300 MPa, 20 min duration, and a liquid-to-solid ratio of 2.5 ml/g. In peanut-sensitized mice, cAMP treatment reduced allergic symptoms, serum IgE, histamine, and IL-4 levels while increasing TNF-α secretion, suggesting anti-allergic effects.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice sensitized to peanut protein.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of producing cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) from jujube cores and to characterize their morphological, structural, crystallinity, and thermal properties.
results_summary: The study successfully generated CNCs from jujube cores, demonstrating rod-like shapes with preserved cellulose Iβ crystal structure, 72.36% crystallinity, and good thermal stability (>200 °C). The CNCs exhibited slight agglomeration in aqueous suspension but maintained high hydrophilicity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) fumigation on postharvest senescence and antioxidant metabolism in Lingwu Long Jujube fruits.
results_summary: H2S fumigation significantly prolonged shelf life, reduced decay and weight loss, and maintained fruit quality by delaying oxidative damage and enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity. It also inhibited the loss of key nutrients like chlorophyll, carotenoids, and ascorbic acid.
population_specificity: Lingwu Long Jujube fruits (Ziziphus jujuba cv. Mill)
study_duration: Postharvest storage period (specific duration not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant and antitumor effects of jujube polysaccharides alone and in combination with ginger 6-gingerol (G6G) on SW620 cells.
results_summary: Jujube polysaccharides (ZJPs-II) and G6G alone showed dose-dependent antioxidant and antitumor effects, while their combination demonstrated synergistic interactions, enhancing apoptosis and cell-cycle arrest in SW620 cells.
population_specificity: In vitro study using SW620 human colon cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of dried Ziziphus jujube on blood glucose, lipid profiles, anthropometric indices, and inflammatory factors in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study found that daily consumption of Ziziphus jujube significantly reduced fasting plasma glucose, triglycerides, total cholesterol, LDL-C, and hs-CRP levels in type 2 diabetic patients, though hs-CRP reduction was not significant compared to the control group. No significant changes were observed in body mass index, HDL-C, or IL-6 levels.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients aged 30-65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of jujube peel polyphenols in LPS-induced RAW 264.7 cells, focusing on MAPK, NF-κB, and Nrf2 signaling pathways.
results_summary: Jujube peel polyphenols reduced TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, NO, and PGE2 by inhibiting MAPK and NF-κB pathways and activating Nrf2, thereby alleviating oxidative stress and inflammation. The study suggests a synergistic anti-inflammatory effect in LPS-induced RAW 264.7 cells.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 cells (a murine macrophage cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of jujube syrup for brightening facial skin and reducing hyperpigmentation.
results_summary: Jujube syrup significantly reduced the number of pigment counts, pigmented area, and its percentages compared to placebo, demonstrating efficacy in treating facial hyperpigmentation. The syrup was also found to be stable under accelerated conditions, with quantified amounts of beneficial compounds like phenolics, flavonoids, and organic acids.
population_specificity: 46 participants (23 in the jujube syrup group and 23 in the placebo group) in a randomized, double-blind, controlled clinical study.
effective_dosage: Twice a day (specific volume not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of jujube polysaccharides on oral biofilm-forming pathogenic bacteria and their potential as an alternative to antibiotics in dental practice.
results_summary: Jujube polysaccharides demonstrated significant inhibitory effects against oral bacterial pathogens, including growth inhibition, biofilm disruption, and modulation of inflammatory responses, while positively regulating oral microbiota.
population_specificity: Oral biofilm-forming pathogenic bacteria (Streptococcus mutans, MRSA, Porphyromonas gingivalis) and general oral microbiota.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different extraction methods on the flavonoid content, composition, and stability in jujube.
results_summary: The study found that DES-MAE yielded the highest total flavonoid content (8.03 mg/g), identified 15 types of flavonoids, and demonstrated that DES-UAE was efficient for flavonoid extraction with high retention rates under various storage conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on jujube extracts)
study_duration: Not specified (focused on extraction and stability testing)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of phytoplasma resistance in Chinese jujube, comparing a resistant genotype ("T13") and a susceptible cultivar ("Pozao").
results_summary: The study found that resistant jujube ("T13") exhibited differential gene expression only in the initial growth phase post-infection, with no phytoplasma detected in later phases. Hormonal and ROS signaling, particularly involving JA and SA, played key roles in resistance, and exogenous SA inhibition alleviated disease symptoms.
population_specificity: Chinese jujube plants (Ziziphus jujuba Mill.), specifically resistant genotype "T13" and susceptible cultivar "Pozao."

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chlorine and ultrasound treatments in disinfecting winter jujube and preventing pathogen cross-contamination while maintaining fruit quality.
results_summary: The combination of 28 kHz ultrasound and 10 ppm free chlorine completely eliminated pathogen cross-contamination and significantly reduced microbial counts without negatively affecting the fruit's sensory, nutritional, or quality properties during storage.
population_specificity: Winter jujube (uncut ready-to-eat fruit).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a non-thermal processing method (HHP-VFD) on the flavor quality and shelf life of fruit and vegetable blends, including Jujube.
results_summary: The HHP-VFD treatment maintained volatile compound contents, increased floral-like volatile compounds (e.g., β-ionone), and preserved overall sensory liking without significant flavor reduction. The method also improved shelf life and portability.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general fruit and vegetable blends, including Jujube).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how propyl gallate (PG) affects the post-harvest physiological quality of winter jujube, focusing on antioxidant metabolism and peel structure.
results_summary: PG treatment delayed peel color change, improved firmness, total soluble solids, and titratable acid content, enhanced antioxidant levels (total phenols, flavonoids, AsA, GSH), maintained higher enzyme activity (SOD, CAT, APX, POD), and reduced oxidative damage markers (EL, LOX, H2O2, MDA).
population_specificity: Winter jujube fruits
effective_dosage: 0.001 mol L-1 PG solution for 20 min

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiarrheal effects of jujube honey in mice with castor oil-induced diarrhea, assessing its impact on diarrhea onset, stool output, inflammation, and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Diluted jujube honey significantly delayed diarrhea onset, reduced wet stools, and improved oxidative stress markers (SOD, catalase) while lowering inflammation markers (CRP, NO). It also inhibited intestinal transit, suggesting a mechanism for its antidiarrheal effect.
population_specificity: Mice with castor oil-induced diarrhea.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diluted jujube honey and undiluted forms were tested).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of the salt-tolerant antagonistic bacteria CZ-6 (Bacillus amyloliquefaciens) to improve winter jujube growth and resistance to soil salinization and fungal diseases.
results_summary: The study found that CZ-6 strain survived in high-salt conditions, produced growth-promoting compounds, inhibited pathogenic fungi, and altered the rhizosphere microbial community to favor salt-tolerant bacteria while reducing pathogens. It also colonized and migrated within winter jujube plants, suggesting potential for biological control in saline soils.
population_specificity: Winter jujube plants grown in saline soil conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Ziziphus spina-christi (Jujube) root extract and its silver nanoparticles on mitochondrial fatty acid oxidation, adipokine secretion, and vascular endothelial cell growth in relation to obesity and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that ZS-Ag-NPs significantly reduced lipid content in adipocytes (82%), enhanced lipolysis-related gene expression, decreased insulin resistance and inflammation markers, and improved vascular endothelial cell growth while reducing oxidative stress and inflammation.
population_specificity: Maturing adipocytes and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of heat shock (HT), 1-methylcyclopropene (1-MCP), or their combination on preserving the quality of fresh jujube fruits during cold storage.
results_summary: HT treatment was most effective in preserving jujube quality by inhibiting decay, weight loss, and maintaining firmness, soluble solids, acidity, and ascorbic acid content. It also delayed cell wall degradation and maintained high activity of antioxidant enzymes compared to other treatments.
population_specificity: Fresh jujube fruits
study_duration: Duration of cold storage not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if jujube powder could enhance the efficiency of cyclophosphamide (CTX) chemotherapy by nurturing gut microbiota and improving immune responses.
results_summary: Jujube powder enriched CD8+ T cells in the tumor microenvironment, increased gut microbiota diversity, boosted Bifidobacteriales abundance, and stimulated white blood cell production while inhibiting eosinophils and certain cytokines, leading to significant tumor growth inhibition.
population_specificity: Mice with MC38 colon tumors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of ultrafine jujube powder (JP) on gut microbiota and its potential to enhance the response to anti-PD-L1 immunotherapy in murine colon adenocarcinoma.
results_summary: JP improved anti-PD-L1 treatment response by altering gut microbiota, increasing Clostridiales abundance, elevating SCFA production, and boosting CD8+ T cell infiltration in tumors. The findings suggest JP enhances immune checkpoint blockade therapy efficacy.
population_specificity: Murine colon adenocarcinoma model (mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficiency of ultrasound-assisted adsorption/desorption for purifying jujube peel flavonoids using macroporous resins and its impact on flavonoid content and biological activities.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound treatment significantly increased the adsorption/desorption capacity of jujube peel flavonoids (80.21 mg/g and 76.22 mg/g, respectively) and enhanced the content of principal individual flavonoids by 2-3 times compared to shaking treatment, along with improved biological activities.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various green pretreatment methods (cold plasma, ultrasonics, etc.) as alternatives to chemical pretreatment for improving the drying process and quality properties of whole jujube.
results_summary: Cold plasma, thermosonication, and chemical pretreatments improved drying rates, increased phenolic content and antioxidant capacity, and reduced 5-hydroxymethylfurfural generation. Cold plasma was identified as a promising green alternative to chemical pretreatment.
population_specificity: Whole jujube (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if leucine-rich protein supplementation at key intervals could mitigate frailty progression and enhance postoperative recovery in cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Frail and older cardiac surgery patients with multiple comorbidities.
effective_dosage: Two times per day (specific amount not mentioned).
study_duration: Approximately 2 weeks pre-procedure, during in-hospital recovery, and for 8 weeks post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of leucine supplementation, alone or combined with other nutrients and/or physical exercise, on sarcopenia in older adults.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation alone without physical exercise did not improve sarcopenia markers, but leucine paired with other supplements, particularly leucine-enriched protein supplements, showed promise in improving sarcopenic markers, with or without physical exercise.
population_specificity: Older adults over 60 years of age with a history of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate leucine's potential to preserve lean mass in cancer cachexia by modulating protein turnover and immune response, as well as its impact on tumor growth.
results_summary: Leucine supplementation was found to increase protein synthesis and decrease protein degradation via mTORC1 activation, potentially attenuating cancer cachexia symptoms, though methodological differences complicate comparisons across studies. Further research is needed to clarify leucine's effects on protein turnover, immune response, and tumor growth.
population_specificity: Pre-clinical studies involving cachectic tumor-bearing hosts (animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a leucine-enriched muscle-targeted oral nutritional supplementation (MT-ONS) is effective for treating or preventing sarcopenia in older patients.
results_summary: The study found that MT-ONS significantly increased muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in older patients with sarcopenia, with consistent results across various clinical settings. It also showed a positive effect on inflammation markers and healthcare resource consumption.
population_specificity: Older patients with sarcopenia or at risk of losing skeletal muscle mass, including those in rehabilitation centers, care homes, and community settings.
